resources.string: Hint: Disable this confirmation dialog in the settings...

Battery Indicator will be completely closed, and you won\'t see it in your status bar any more.\n
\nIf you just want to leave the main window and keep the indicator running, press Cancel and then just press your device\'s BACK button to leave the main window.

Thanks for your donation/purchase! These two points are very important :


• If you have a "task killer" / process manager of some kind, you should either uninstall it or try to get it to ignore Battery Indicator Pro. Even if you have it set to ignore the free version, you still need to tell it to ignore this Pro version !


• If you have a Motorola Droid, Droid X, Droid 2, Defy, or Samsung Moment, you should turn on "10% Mode" in the "Other Settings".

Thanks for downloading Battery Indicator! This is important :\n
\nIf you have a \"task killer\" / process manager of some kind, you should either uninstall it or try to get it to ignore Battery Indicator.

This is Battery Indicator, the free version of the Battery Indicator family of apps. It\'s available from the Android Market, and it\'s an open source project, which means you can download the source for free from the project website.\n
\nPlease consider donating by upgrading to the Pro Version.

Battery Indicator is a lightweight battery indicator for the Android™ mobile operating system. Its core feature is that it provides an icon that lives in the status bar and shows you the percentage of battery charge left.


The Pro version offers a great deal more utility than that, however. Besides offering red, amber, and green icons, it also has the following key features as of version 3.0:


• Fully configurable estimated charge/discharge time left. 
• Downloadable icon plugins. 
• Logging of battery state. 
• Themes for the main window (including a full-size window with large, easy-to-read text). 
• Manually disable/reenable the device lock screen, with the option to automatically disable it when plugged in and reenable it when unplugged. 
• Many more useful things that you'll discover throughout.

(These are out of my control.)


• The app can only display what the device tells it. Most devices report every 1%, but a few (notably the Motorola Droid models) only report every 10%. 
• There's no way to remove the built-in battery icon. 
• The notification icon in the status bar and the message you see in the notification tray are tied together — you can't have one without the other. 
• Many apps should allow installation to removable storage (SD card); some should not. Battery Indicator is of the latter group. See the project FAQ if you'd like further explanation.

• Small, simple, and easy to read. 
• It doesn't do any polling. It receives a broadcast message from the OS when the battery status changes, then it simply updates the icon and goes back to sleep. What this means is that it will take up a small amount of RAM, but essentially 0 CPU cycles, so it can't drain your battery. I estimate that it will cost you about 1 minute of usage time off of a full discharge as a worst case scenario. If you are experiencing anything worse than that, you probably have another app (such as a "task killer" app of some kind) interfering with Battery Indicator's normal operation. 
• Easy access to Battery Use screen (requires Android 1.6+). 
• Configure to always start on boot, never start on boot, or start on boot if the app was running on shutdown. 
• Lots more that I'm either forgetting or seem too minor to mention on their on, but that add up to a great app. 
• The satisfaction of supporting the developer. (I really appreciate it!)

This software is distributed in the hope that it will be useful, but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.\n
\nWhile I do my best to make sure that it works well and does not cause problems, I am not responsible for any damage or inconvenience it may cause under any circumstance.

This app would only be available in English without the generous assistance of the volunteer translators. Thanks!


Many thanks are due to Google and all of the open-source coders who made the Android platform and this app possible.


The launcher icon (the upright battery you see in the Market) is based on an icon from the Oxygen icon theme and used under the Creative Common Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 License.

I need help translating this app to other languages. If you would like to help, please send me an email. (This address is only for translation; see Contact section below for all other inquiries.) Unless you prefer me not to, I will add your name to this section in acknowledgment of your assistance.
If you have a question or a problem, please see the project FAQ for how to contact me.\n

The Pro version has many more settings and features, including colorful icons, downloadable icon plugins, alarms, window themes, battery state logging, auto/manual lock screen disable, charge/discharge remaining estimates, and more.
Android reports the battery temperature in degrees Celsius. If you prefer to see the battery temperature in degrees Fahrenheit, check this option, and the app will convert for you.
Start Battery Indicator when device boots:

Controls whether Battery Indicator should start itself automatically when the device boots up.\n
\nThe \"If Running on Shutdown\" option works with regard to whether you\'ve most recently manually started or stopped Battery Indicator. So if you kill Battery Indicator through some other means, like a task killer, then Battery Indicator doesn\'t know you stopped it, and it will still start at boot up if you have it set to this.
Show the charge level as larger text next to icon?

I\'ve had a few users with poorer eyesight ask me to add this option, whereby the charge level is displayed as text (which is a bit larger and easier to read) right next to the icon when you pull down the notification area. The actual icon won\'t be any different, so this will only help when you pull down the notification tray, but it\'s better than nothing, and easy enough to add for those that want it.\n
\nTo save precious space, I\'ve done this in a very unglamorous fashion, simply plopping the number in there and carrying on. This turns out to be easier to read than if I included the percent symbol, and means that the text should all fit. It is possible that if you have a particularly small device, enabling this might make the AM/PM at the far right not quite fit.
Start approximating hours since status change:

Determines when the notification switches from saying, e.g., \"Unplugged Since 1:10 PM\" to saying something like \"Unplugged for 1 Hour\". The first way is more accurate, because it tells you exactly (to the minute) when the status changed, but many people prefer the simpler to comprehend approximation of the number of elapsed hours, so they make that happen sooner than the default of 12 hours.
